title: Dear salty players who don't like me "feeding" (learning Azir) in their norms,
body:
I know I'm really bad, I don't need to hear the 5000th person say it,

I'm still learning how to drift and cs as Azir properly,

I can't be perfect, I can't hit every ult of mine perfectly,

I'm trying my hardest,

I'm not in your ranked games,

http://i1068.photobucket.com/albums/u450/Schniner/Deal%20With%20It.png

EDIT: It seems people think I'm referring to going into a game with no idea how to play a champion. This isn't what I'm talking about, I'm referring to practicing and mastering a champion rather than just figuring out what the abilities do.

First I want to say I completely agree with you 100% Eternal Zen. 

I do want to say however, that while I do think Dragfin is extremely childish and narrow minded, not to mention everything else you say. I do feel there is a middle ground between both of your extreme views. 
 
While he wants to bash everyone who isn't "good", and you are totally ok with everyone no matter the situation, I do feel there is a middle ground. 

I think most of DragFins annoyances and pissy attitude come from people who say "It's just a game" and leave it at that. It's these people that are I believe who he's calling selfish, and disrespectful. Sure, they play, and I am not within the righto bitch at them for being as good as I am, that doesnt' mean they are in the right to simply say "well its just a game" and not try. There are people who use this excuse to not better themselves, and continue to make the game hell for their teammates and doing the most simplistic day 1 mistakes 3 years down the road. I do not believe they either have this right, as it all comes down to respect. 

While I agree with the OP, normals by all means, is a place to practice, play, and have fun. Nobody has a right to complain to them for not being awesome at the champ they chose. 

On the flip side, it is a game, and a game is meant to be played properly and in the way it was intended to be played. There are a handful of people, (more than I care to admit), who simply log in, screw around in a game, and albeit playing it properly, really don't care about anything than spamming a few buttons, csing some stuff and logging off. This isn't entirely respectful either, and is just as bad as DragFin in all honesty. 

If you're going to play a competitive game, where the objective is to beat the other team, but you're the only one on the team, not caring to do your best, or trying to learn and get better, then you also are a problem, and in that sense, people do have the right to complain in my personal opinion. 

----------------------

"It's just a game", is never a legitimate remark or defense, because it's not just a game, and is in no way an excuse to screw around or not take it seriously. It's also the time of the players on your team and the opposing team trying to have a good, fun  match, and that attitude generally results in pissing people off one way or another. 

Like-wise, you're entering a competitive team based game. This naturally by its very nature, is going to attract all the serious players, and players who want to win, play the game to its most, and do the best they can. Then there are players who just aren't good, or don't care. 

Neither of them are inherently wrong, but both need to respect each other, unfortunately in this situation, the ones who are less competitive and don't take the game seriously, need to respect that this game is not for them in the long run, and should respect those who wish to play it properly and get better at it.

I looked through your games, OP, and I have a couple of build suggestions...

First off, don't take ignite with Azir. As a general rule, you shouldn't be close enough to your opponent to cast ignite on them. Barrier is generally my go-to with Azir. Secondly, I always rush Nashor's Tooth first with a second Doran's Ring to help with mana. My standard item order is generally; {{item:1056}} {{item:2003}} {{item:2003}} > {{item:3108}} {{item:1056}}  > {{item:3101}} > {{item:3115}} > {{item:3116}} > anything else. (Boots somewhere in the early/mid game.) Of course, it's going to be situational depending on what you need for defenses, but if all is going well, that's what I do. Not sure of what you do with your skill order, but most agree on R > Q > W > E.

Also, QUICK CAST WITHOUT INDICATOR. It's hard to get used to, but it's almost always a good idea on any champ. It forces you not to hesitate to cast abilities and helps you learn to keep track of yourself better while visualizing your own range.

If I could make a suggestion?

Consider taking Teleport over Barrier. A lot of the time, Barrier isn't going to save you in a teamfight (especially if they're an all in comp, which Azir is weak to) and in lane it's usually a better idea to uber farm and poke from out of range than it is to go for a duel since that early on your dps is very limited to a single Q. Teleport is... well, I mean it's teleport. Map Presence. The lowered CDR also works on your passive turret so something I do a lot of the time is go to their inner turret, set mine down, B and tele back and siege with full resources. 

I just feel it's much stronger than barrier for Azir, I've been running Teleport on Azir since about a week after he released and I realized ignite is utterly useless for him.

The thing is, is that in the end, it's just Normals. It's not like it's Ranked, where your wins matter. Sure, you lose a Normal because someone wanted to try a new champion. The way the community should work would be to try to support the player who's playing a new champion. Make them feel better about making their selection, give them pointers, help them secure kills, be a good player.
